required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on May 29, 2018
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Evaluation of the Use of Metal Stents as Part of the Treatment of Benign Biliary Strictures
clinical_study.official_title: Prospective Evaluation of the Clinical Utility of Placement of Metal Stent for Benign Biliary Strictures

brief_summary.textblock: The purpose of this study is to study the evaluation of the use of metal stents as part of the treatment of benign biliary strictures.

detailed_description.textblock: In patients with benign biliary strictures, the use of fully covered self-expandable metal stents (SEMS) has been proposed as an alternative to plastic stenting, but high quality prospective data is sparse. This study was performed to evaluate the long -term effectiveness and safety of a new fully covered SEMS for benign biliary strictures.

primary_outcome.measure: Short Term Success Rate in the Resolution of Biliary Strictures
primary_outcome.description: Short-term success was defined as resolution of the stricture as documented by rapid drainage of contrast out of the proximal biliary tree and easy passage of stone extraction balloon inflated to the size of the proximal bile duct. If the biliary stricture had resolved at the 6-month follow-up ERCP, patients were classified as short-term success. If stricture was not resolved at 6-month ERCP then a new SEMS was placed; if the stricture had resolved at the time of the second stent removal, the patient was also classified as short-term success.

primary_outcome.measure: Long-term Success Rate in Resolution of Biliary Strictures
primary_outcome.time_frame: at least 12 months after stent removal
primary_outcome.description: Long-term success was defined as no clinical evidence of recurrence of the biliary stricture during the follow-up period as documented by laboratory findings or imaging and no further need for further endoscopic or surgical interventions.

secondary_outcome.measure: Number of Endoscopic Treatments Per Patient
secondary_outcome.description: The average number of ERCPs performed per patient required for resolution of benign strictures.
The ease of stent removal was graded on a 4-point scale (with ease, mild difficulty, significant difficulty, and failed).

secondary_outcome.measure: Frequency and Severity of Adverse Events (Including Stent Migration)
secondary_outcome.description: Adverse events were defined and graded using the 2010 American Society for Gastrointestinal Endoscopy consensus criteria

arm_group.description: All patients who have a medical indication for an ERCP to place a stent in their benign biliary strictures

intervention.description: Endoscopic Retrograde Cholangiopancreatography (ERCP) with placement of metal stent in the bile duct

study_pop.textblock: Patients who have a medical indication for endoscopic therapy of benign biliary stictures and are referred for the procedure as part of their standard medical care will be considered for the study.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
1. Subject is 18 years or older
2. Subject has benign biliary stricture
3. Subject must be able to give informed consent
Exclusion Criteria:
1. Any contraindication to Endoscopic Retrograde Cholangiopancreatography (ERCP)
2. The subject is unable to give informed consent

group.title: Benign Biliary Strictures
group.description: Participants underwent Endoscopic Retrograde Cholangiopancreatography (ERCP) with placement of self-expandable metal stents (SEMS) in the bile duct.

group.title: Benign Biliary Strictures
group.description: Participants underwent Endoscopic Retrograde Cholangiopancreatography (ERCP) with placement of self-expandable metal stents (SEMS) in the bile duct.

measure.title: number of participants with history of prior stenting

class.title: number with no history of stenting

outcome.title: Short Term Success Rate in the Resolution of Biliary Strictures
outcome.description: Short-term success was defined as resolution of the stricture as documented by rapid drainage of contrast out of the proximal biliary tree and easy passage of stone extraction balloon inflated to the size of the proximal bile duct. If the biliary stricture had resolved at the 6-month follow-up ERCP, patients were classified as short-term success. If stricture was not resolved at 6-month ERCP then a new SEMS was placed; if the stricture had resolved at the time of the second stent removal, the patient was also classified as short-term success.
outcome.population: Of the 23 participants that entered the study, 22 saw short-term success. The population consisted of 14 Chronic pancreatitis patients, 4 postorthotopic liver transplant patients, and 5 others.

group.title: Benign Biliary Strictures
group.description: Participants underwent Endoscopic Retrograde Cholangiopancreatography (ERCP) with placement of self-expandable metal stents (SEMS) in the bile duct.

measure.title: Short Term Success Rate in the Resolution of Biliary Strictures
measure.description: Short-term success was defined as resolution of the stricture as documented by rapid drainage of contrast out of the proximal biliary tree and easy passage of stone extraction balloon inflated to the size of the proximal bile duct. If the biliary stricture had resolved at the 6-month follow-up ERCP, patients were classified as short-term success. If stricture was not resolved at 6-month ERCP then a new SEMS was placed; if the stricture had resolved at the time of the second stent removal, the patient was also classified as short-term success.
measure.population: Of the 23 participants that entered the study, 22 saw short-term success. The population consisted of 14 Chronic pancreatitis patients, 4 postorthotopic liver transplant patients, and 5 others.

outcome.title: Long-term Success Rate in Resolution of Biliary Strictures
outcome.description: Long-term success was defined as no clinical evidence of recurrence of the biliary stricture during the follow-up period as documented by laboratory findings or imaging and no further need for further endoscopic or surgical interventions.
outcome.time_frame: at least 12 months after stent removal
outcome.population: Per-protocol analysis, the 18 participants available for long term success follow-up consisted of: 11 with CP, 3 with OLT, and 4 others. Intention to treat analysis of long-term success consisted of 22 overall patients, 12 CP patients, 3 OLT patients, and 7 other patients. This analysis included all patients lost to follow-up as long-term failures.

measure.description: Long-term success was defined as no clinical evidence of recurrence of the biliary stricture during the follow-up period as documented by laboratory findings or imaging and no further need for further endoscopic or surgical interventions.
measure.population: Per-protocol analysis, the 18 participants available for long term success follow-up consisted of: 11 with CP, 3 with OLT, and 4 others. Intention to treat analysis of long-term success consisted of 22 overall patients, 12 CP patients, 3 OLT patients, and 7 other patients. This analysis included all patients lost to follow-up as long-term failures.

group.title: Benign Biliary Strictures
group.description: Participants underwent Endoscopic Retrograde Cholangiopancreatography (ERCP) with placement of self-expandable metal stents (SEMS) in the bile duct.

measure.title: Ease of Stent Removal
measure.description: The ease of stent removal was graded on a 4-point scale (with ease, mild difficulty, significant difficulty, and failed).

outcome.title: Frequency and Severity of Adverse Events (Including Stent Migration)
outcome.description: Adverse events were defined and graded using the 2010 American Society for Gastrointestinal Endoscopy consensus criteria
outcome.population: Stent migration was seen in 9/23 patients (5 downstream, 4 upstream). It was without clinical complications except in one case. Post-procedure pain experienced by 1 patient was effectively treated by downgrading the stent size to a smaller diameter.

group.title: Benign Biliary Strictures
group.description: Participants underwent Endoscopic Retrograde Cholangiopancreatography (ERCP) with placement of self-expandable metal stents (SEMS) in the bile duct.

class.title: Postprocedure pain due to expansion force of SEMS

group.title: Benign Biliary Strictures
group.description: Participants underwent Endoscopic Retrograde Cholangiopancreatography (ERCP) with placement of self-expandable metal stents (SEMS) in the bile duct.

event.description: 9 subjects (39.1% of participants) had stent migration and required additional endoscopy to remove the stent

certain_agreements.pi_employee: All Principal Investigators ARE employed by the organization sponsoring the study.
certain_agreements.restrictive_agreement: There is NOT an agreement between Principal Investigators and the Sponsor (or its agents) that restricts the PI's rights to discuss or publish trial results after the trial is completed.

clinical_results.limitations_and_caveats: Fifty-six percent of our patients had prior therapy for their benign biliary stricture; therefore they were not treatment naive. High prevalence of CP-related strictures which are known to be more difficult to treat.
